description:
osmFISH is a cyclic single molecule fluorescent in situ hybridization protocol used to quantify the expression level of specific transcripts in tissue sections by direct labeling of individual RNA molecules. The number of transcripts quantified in each round correspond the numbers of fluorophores available in the microscope setup. In order to quantify a large number of genes, osmFISH provides a method to remove the probes/labelling (stripping) from their targets and get the tissue ready for the next round of labeling - imaging - stripping.

 

Even though the osmFISH protocol has been developed to perform multiple smFISH rounds, it can also be used as a quick and simple method for one-round smFISH. Furthermore, the protocol can be further extended to include more complex encoding/barcoding shemes that can be used to resolve a larger number of targets.
before_start:
Please reed our considerations about the imaging and hybridization chamber setup on our website.

 

Prepare the Hybridization mix. We tipically make 10-40ml, aliquot and freeze at -20°C untill use. 

 

Aliquot the formamide in 200ml aliquots and freeze at -20°C. At the start of each week we thaw wat we need that week.
warning: The protocol requires the handeling of PFA, SDS and formamide. Please read the safety data sheet on these chemicals and handle accordingly. Furthermore the imaging buffer Slow Fade Diamond contains Phenol.
protocol_affiliation: Karolinska Institute Stockholm,Technion - Israel Institute of Technology

groups.group_name: Human Cell Atlas Method Development Community

keywords: smFISH, osmFISH, in situ hybridization, rna, rna detection, spatial transcriptomics, transcriptomics, multiplexed,
authors: simone codeluppi,Lars Borm,amit zeisel,Gioele La Manno,Josina A. van Lunteren,Camilla I. Svensson,Sten Linnarsson
guidelines:
The volume of the wash steps are determined by the volume of the flow cell. At least replace the volume once. The wash volume we use is double that of the flow cell. So 2 x 500µl = 1ml per wash, in our case.

 

Stellaris RNA FISH probes were orderd from Biosearch Tecnologies
status_info: We use this protocol in our group and it is working

components.data: Transcardally perfuse a mouse with cold oxygenated artificial spinal fluid solution.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Transcardally perfuse a mouse with cold oxygenated artificial spinal fluid solution.

components.data: Quickly dissect out the brain on a cold surface.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Quickly dissect out the brain on a cold surface.

components.data: Place the brain in cryomold and fill it up with Tissue-Tek O.C.T. (Sakura)
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Place the brain in cryomold and fill it up with Tissue-Tek O.C.T. (Sakura)

components.data: Snap freeze the sample by lowering the cryomold in a slush of isopentane and dry ice. Make sure to prepare the slush before dissection and wait to use it until the bubbling stops.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Snap freeze the sample by lowering the cryomold in a slush of isopentane and dry ice. Make sure to prepare the slush before dissection and wait to use it until the bubbling stops.
Store sample at -80°C.

components.data: Empty a box of coverslips (#1.5) in a beaker. Rinse coverslips in distilled water two times for 20 min.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Empty a box of coverslips (#1.5) in a beaker. Rinse coverslips in distilled water two times for 20 min.

source_data.annotation:
Do you have any recommendations for coverslips you used? (Cat#/vendor)?

Also, why do you mount the tissue on a coverslip as opposed to a slide? To reduce volume? I'm thinking about how fragile a coverslip is and how easy it would be to break. If I wanted to do just one round to test this protocol, would it be OK do mount to a Superfrost slide?
source_data.thread_text:
Do you have any recommendations for coverslips you used? (Cat#/vendor)?

Also, why do you mount the tissue on a coverslip as opposed to a slide? To reduce volume? I'm thinking about how fragile a coverslip is and how easy it would be to break. If I wanted to do just one round to test this protocol, would it be OK do mount to a Superfrost slide?
source_data.body:
Do you have any recommendations for coverslips you used? (Cat#/vendor)?

Also, why do you mount the tissue on a coverslip as opposed to a slide? To reduce volume? I'm thinking about how fragile a coverslip is and how easy it would be to break. If I wanted to do just one round to test this protocol, would it be OK do mount to a Superfrost slide?

comments.name: Lars Borm
comments.comment_text:
We use #1.5 24x32mm coverslips from Marienfeld Cat. 0102172. The reason that we use coverslips and not slides, is that most high magnification/NA objectives have a short working distance. So short, that if you mount your sample on a regular microscope slide, it is too thick and it is not possible to get the sample into focus. The coverslips are indeed a bit more fragile but not as fragile as you would think. Just carfully break one before you start so that you know what the limit is. (If you plan to use Grace Biolabs hybridization chambers, either do not remove them to do the imaging or practice with removing them because this can be tricky.)

 

If you just want to try the protocol it might be possible to use a regular microscope slide and coverslip embedding, but again it all depends on the working distance of the objective. If you do not want to go through the trouble of doing the APS coating, it is possible to use polylysine coated coverslides. They work fine for one round, but we saw that the tissue can detach a bit in the later rounds.
comments.body:
We use #1.5 24x32mm coverslips from Marienfeld Cat. 0102172. The reason that we use coverslips and not slides, is that most high magnification/NA objectives have a short working distance. So short, that if you mount your sample on a regular microscope slide, it is too thick and it is not possible to get the sample into focus. The coverslips are indeed a bit more fragile but not as fragile as you would think. Just carfully break one before you start so that you know what the limit is. (If you plan to use Grace Biolabs hybridization chambers, either do not remove them to do the imaging or practice with removing them because this can be tricky.)

 

If you just want to try the protocol it might be possible to use a regular microscope slide and coverslip embedding, but again it all depends on the working distance of the objective. If you do not want to go through the trouble of doing the APS coating, it is possible to use polylysine coated coverslides. They work fine for one round, but we saw that the tissue can detach a bit in the later rounds.

comments.name: Alexander Chamessian
comments.comment_text: Thank you for this very thorough explanation. I'll use the coverslip as you do.
comments.body: Thank you for this very thorough explanation. I'll use the coverslip as you do.

components.data: Incubate the coverslips in concentrated nitic acid for 24 hours.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Incubate the coverslips in concentrated nitic acid for 24 hours.

comments.name: Lars Borm
comments.comment_text: It could be but we did not try this. The reason of this step is to clean the glass of any contaminants like fats. Nitric acid is a bit more oxidative than CHl.
comments.body: It could be but we did not try this. The reason of this step is to clean the glass of any contaminants like fats. Nitric acid is a bit more oxidative than CHl.

components.data: Rinse coverslips in water 4 times for 1 hour.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Rinse coverslips in water 4 times for 1 hour.

components.data: Fill the beaker with distilled water and sterilize the coverslips by autoclaving.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Fill the beaker with distilled water and sterilize the coverslips by autoclaving.

components.data: Wash coverslips once with 95% ethanol and store them indefinitively in 95% ethanol.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Wash coverslips once with 95% ethanol and store them indefinitively in 95% ethanol.

components.data: Place the coverslips to use in a rack and air dry to remove the ethanol.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Place the coverslips to use in a rack and air dry to remove the ethanol.

components.data:
Prepare 2% (3-Aminopropyl)triethoxysilane, APS (v/v)(Sigma) in acetone in a staing jar. Make sure to use fresh APS that has been stored in a dry environment.

Dip the rack with the coverslips for 1 minute in the solution, followed by a 1 minute dip in RNAse free water.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Prepare 2% (3-Aminopropyl)triethoxysilane, APS (v/v)(Sigma) in acetone in a staing jar. Make sure to use fresh APS that has been stored in a dry environment.

Dip the rack with the coverslips for 1 minute in the solution, followed by a 1 minute dip in RNAse free water.

components.data: Air dry the coverslips and store them in a dessicated envirionment.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Air dry the coverslips and store them in a dessicated envirionment.

components.data: Cryocut 10µm thick sections of the fresh frozen tissue and mount the section on the functionalized coverslips. In order to remove the electostatic charge of the coverslip clean one side of the coverslip with a kimwipe wetted with ethanol.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Cryocut 10µm thick sections of the fresh frozen tissue and mount the section on the functionalized coverslips. In order to remove the electostatic charge of the coverslip clean one side of the coverslip with a kimwipe wetted with ethanol.

components.data:
Make a fixing chamber by cutting a hole in a piece of parafilm and place it in a petri dish. The parafilm functions as a spacer to separate the tissue section from the bottom of the petri dish. The number of chambers matchs the number of sections that will be cut. Place a drop of 4% PFA in the a clean petri dish inside the hole in the parafilm. 

Directly after capture, fix the section with 4% PFA for 10minutes by placing the tissue section face down on the PFA drop. 

 

Suggestion

We saw that PFA soultion prepared from powder causes lower background compared to commercial PFA solutions. However, we didn't test all the solutions available in the market.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Make a fixing chamber by cutting a hole in a piece of parafilm and place it in a petri dish. The parafilm functions as a spacer to separate the tissue section from the bottom of the petri dish. The number of chambers matchs the number of sections that will be cut. Place a drop of 4% PFA in the a clean petri dish inside the hole in the parafilm. 

Directly after capture, fix the section with 4% PFA for 10minutes by placing the tissue section face down on the PFA drop. 

 

Suggestion

We saw that PFA soultion prepared from powder causes lower background compared to commercial PFA solutions. However, we didn't test all the solutions available in the market.

components.data: After fixation transfer the glass to a clean petri dish and rinse twice with PBS.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: After fixation transfer the glass to a clean petri dish and rinse twice with PBS.

components.data: Remove the excess of PBS and dry the slide with a tissue without touching the tissue.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove the excess of PBS and dry the slide with a tissue without touching the tissue.

components.data: Dehydrate the slide in >1ml of isopropanol for 3 minutes. Followed by air drying.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Dehydrate the slide in >1ml of isopropanol for 3 minutes. Followed by air drying.
Store the slide at -80°C untill use.

components.data:
Assemble the sample in the flow cell.

 

We use a custom flow cell that was manufactured by Microliquid. A flow cell facilitates the automation. Please see our notes on the osmFISH website.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Assemble the sample in the flow cell.

 

We use a custom flow cell that was manufactured by Microliquid. A flow cell facilitates the automation. Please see our notes on the osmFISH website.

components.data: Rehydrate the tissue for 5 minutes with 2X SSC buffer.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Rehydrate the tissue for 5 minutes with 2X SSC buffer.

components.data: Clear the tissue by incubating the tissue with 4% SDS in 200mM boric-acid pH 8.5 4 times for 5 minutes.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Clear the tissue by incubating the tissue with 4% SDS in 200mM boric-acid pH 8.5 4 times for 5 minutes.

source_data.annotation: Adjust the volume of the buffer to the volume of the flow cell. At least replace the liquid once. The wash volume that we use is double that of the flow cell. So 2x 500ul = 1ml
source_data.thread_text: Adjust the volume of the buffer to the volume of the flow cell. At least replace the liquid once. The wash volume that we use is double that of the flow cell. So 2x 500ul = 1ml
source_data.body: Adjust the volume of the buffer to the volume of the flow cell. At least replace the liquid once. The wash volume that we use is double that of the flow cell. So 2x 500ul = 1ml

source_data.description: Wash the section with SSC 2X 5 times.

components.data: Wash the tissue twice with Tris EDTA buffer pH 8.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Wash the tissue twice with Tris EDTA buffer pH 8.

components.data: Perform a heat shock by placing the sample at 70°C for 10 min.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Perform a heat shock by placing the sample at 70°C for 10 min.
Promptly wash 3 times with SSC 2X

components.data:
Incubate the tissue with hybridization mix without probes for 5 minutes at room temperature. 

 

Hybrization mix without probes:

2X SSC (Sigma)

10% (w/v) Dextran sulfate (Sigma)

10% (v/v) Formamide (Ambion)

1 mg/ml E. coli tRNA (Roche)

2mM Ribonucleoside vanadyl complexes (RVC) (Sigma)

0.2 ml/ml Bovine Serum Albumin (Sigma)
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Incubate the tissue with hybridization mix without probes for 5 minutes at room temperature. 

 

Hybrization mix without probes:

2X SSC (Sigma)

10% (w/v) Dextran sulfate (Sigma)

10% (v/v) Formamide (Ambion)

1 mg/ml E. coli tRNA (Roche)

2mM Ribonucleoside vanadyl complexes (RVC) (Sigma)

0.2 ml/ml Bovine Serum Albumin (Sigma)

components.data:
Incubate the tissue with hybridization mix with probes for 4 hours at 38.5°C. 

 

Hybrization mix with probes:

2X SSC (Sigma)

10% (w/v) Dextran sulfate (Sigma)

10% (v/v) Formamide (Ambion)

1 mg/ml E. coli tRNA (Roche)

2mM Ribonucleoside vanadyl complexes (RVC) (Sigma)

0.2 ml/ml Bovine Serum Albumin (Sigma)

250nM Probes (Sellaris, LGC Biosearch technologies). ~48 probes/target. The final concentration of each probe set needs is 250nM.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Incubate the tissue with hybridization mix with probes for 4 hours at 38.5°C. 

 

Hybrization mix with probes:

2X SSC (Sigma)

10% (w/v) Dextran sulfate (Sigma)

10% (v/v) Formamide (Ambion)

1 mg/ml E. coli tRNA (Roche)

2mM Ribonucleoside vanadyl complexes (RVC) (Sigma)

0.2 ml/ml Bovine Serum Albumin (Sigma)

250nM Probes (Sellaris, LGC Biosearch technologies). ~48 probes/target. The final concentration of each probe set needs is 250nM.

source_data.annotation: The hybridization temperature is a sensitive parameter and can depend on the calibration of the incubator. Please, make a test to optimize the temperature for your specific incubator. If there is too much background increase the temperature. If there is too little staining decrease the temperature.
source_data.thread_text: The hybridization temperature is a sensitive parameter and can depend on the calibration of the incubator. Please, make a test to optimize the temperature for your specific incubator. If there is too much background increase the temperature. If there is too little staining decrease the temperature.

components.data: Wash 4 times 15 minutes with 20% formamide in 2X SSC at 38.5°C. Add a nuclear staining (ex. Hoechst, Dapi) if needed.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Wash 4 times 15 minutes with 20% formamide in 2X SSC at 38.5°C. Add a nuclear staining (ex. Hoechst, Dapi) if needed.
Wash with 2X SSC.

components.data: Inject Slow Fade Diamond imaging buffer (Thermo). Do not use hardening mounting media in the flow cell. You can use hardening mountine media if the coverslips will be mounted on a slide before imaging.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Inject Slow Fade Diamond imaging buffer (Thermo). Do not use hardening mounting media in the flow cell. You can use hardening mountine media if the coverslips will be mounted on a slide before imaging.

components.data:
Perform imaging of the region of interest.

It is important to save the field of views that are imaged in order to repeat the imaging of the same region. For an extensive discussion on the imaging setup and repeated imaging of the same tissue section please see our website.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:

It is important to save the field of views that are imaged in order to repeat the imaging of the same region. For an extensive discussion on the imaging setup and repeated imaging of the same tissue section please see our website.

components.data: Wash 5 times with SSC 2X to remove the mounting media.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Wash 5 times with SSC 2X to remove the mounting media.

components.data: Strip the probes off of their targets by washing 3 times 10 minutes with 65% formamide in 2X SSC at 30°C.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Strip the probes off of their targets by washing 3 times 10 minutes with 65% formamide in 2X SSC at 30°C.

components.data: Optional: verify if the signal is stripped by imaging.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Optional: verify if the signal is stripped by imaging.
